reviews.review_msg: Ray is awesome.  I've never had a class where the prof is so successful at getting his students engaged and involved.  He held many study groups for his students and even gave us some of his old books.  He's social, helpful and even bought students beer.

No outline or Syllabus. His power points are very helpful - don't miss any class. His comments can be embarrassing, and he most probably is a genius but it's impossible to have philosophical conversations with him (except if you want to be a 'bio-linguist'). He is charming but you have to play the game. It's not so funny.

Funny, personable and helpful. The textbook's his, and is more confusing than he could hope to be. However, if you stick to it and ask questions, his infinite patience will let you do well in the course.

Such a fascinating, witty and humble character. The way he thinks is entirely different, so it may be hard to understand him. But he always makes extra time to help students. Still, if you're not interested in phil then this class will blow your mind.

Is nice and very knowledgeable but mumbles too much and is difficult to understand. Not very helpful either. This class won't be very hard if you're willing to put the work into it, but Ray himself isn't all too great of a prof.
Awesome professor.

Amicable, brilliant, patient, helpful, hilarious, has a most adorable Shih Tzu, can solve 30-line proofs in his head, faster than a speeding bullet, more powerful than a locomotive, able to leap tall buildings in a single bound. Look! Up in the sky! It's a bird. It's a plane. It's Ray Jennings!

I've taken a dozen or so philosophy courses so far and 210 is still my favourite. The material will seem foreign at first, but it won't take long for you to get it. Also, this course is virtually unfailable if you try. Half your mark is homework completion and he pretty much gives you the midterm and final in advance of the examinations.
If you're an idiot you'll do bad in his class. Otherwise you'll be fine.

Ray is a great guy who is also very smart. That being said, I believe that he is not necessarily very in-touch with students' perspectives or experiences: a number of students found him to be confusing, and while he intends to be very helpful, sometimes it just doesn't work out. He seems better suited to teach upper-division or graduate courses.

While Ray is a nice guy, he is not well suited for undergrad. He does not seem to understand how hard this class can be for people. His answer to many of my questions was "read the text," which was even more confusing as he wrote it. Notes are garbled, v. unorganized. Expect yourself to lose the will to live in this class.
One of the best profs ever had. Keep up with the material. Ray is also a very interesting character, very very nice to his students!
made some mistakes, resulting in some confusion, but as long as you follow him and attend class regularly, the mistakes do not make it harder

Extremely irresponsible. It is a dist. ed course and he held lecutres in the library. NEVER reply my emails and never log on to first class. His textbook is very confusing. After the first two weeks, there were only 13 ppl left in the course. Not recommended.

Absolute disaster. Obviously very smart guy, but can't teach, at least not Phil 210. He should stick to his master's students, because he's out of touch with what a 200 level course should look like. Makes a lot of mistakes, resulting in much confusion. Average on the final was 20%, that shows his teaching ability. Stay away!

Helpful professor... BUT BE WARNED: this course is extremely challenging for anyone not used to math. The textbook is very poorly written and the required software is cryptic and has a non-standard interface.  Overall I am quite disappointed with this course as I would love to understand logic, but the pace and level of difficulty are too high.

Ray should teach higher level courses and not 210. He expects too much for a course that has no prerequisites. However, he is EXTREMELY helpful and will spend as long as he needs to to help his students who ask for it.

who GAVE these ratings?! sounds like we had totaly different profs. he can NOT teach. makes endless mistakes:  textbook + software are chalk-full of them. irresponsible: coincidentally sick before every deadline; rarely responds to emails. NO OFFICE HOURS! i wonder how he got a job...and who he bribed for it! too bad it's a pre-req. good luck...

I really didn't know anything about the subject matter, and I did not want to take this course. But from the lectures and the many tutorials, Ray provided the much needed support required for me to achieve an understanding of logic that I would not have believed possible. Also, cudos to the Simon software.  I highly recommend this course!

A wonderful experience.  Very helpful and patient. I'm puzzled that a few students would complain about having the opportunity to learn from one of the great logicians of our time.  People come from around the world come to study with Ray, and his students are scooped up by the best of the best schools on the planet.  Makes you wonder.

An amazing intellect, on a level attained by few. A pleasure to be around. Very helpful. This material is difficult, yet Dr. Jennings goes out of his way to help us understand the material. And by this I mean GENUINELY understand the material, not simply the easily achieved ILLUSION of understanding most students come to expect. Highly recommended.

I don't know why there are no prerequisites for this course. This course has been alright for me but I had to resort to my PHIL 110 skills in order to be able to do this course. Even then, the system of proofs is different so I frequently have to convert back and forth from what I learned and what I have to learn. Ray cannot teach.

Loves to teach. He made me care about logic even though I really didn't care about logic! The course is miserable, but he makes it good. If you have to take 210, you don't want to take it with anyone else. Not to mention, really helpful if you have questions. Cares that you learn.

Not a very hard course. Just do the assignments, and that's  50% of your marks. Exams are little bit harder, especially the final. But since they are hard, students will normally do bad, lol=P I am still rank the 3rd in class even I leave 4 questions blank on the final exam - -! hehe^^

Funny, intelligent, and very nice.  Be prepared to work hard if you take this course.  Sometimes it's hard to understand him simply because the material is tough.  I think he would be great to take logic courses from once you have a firm grasp on the basics.

oh my GOD! this guy can NOT teach...how did he even GET these ratings? he SUCKS! unorganized, does NOT know how to teach, hard to follow, he writes the text and study guide so if you don't understand his lecture, turn to his books...those don't help either! his logic program has so many flaws and he never fixes them ahead of time.

natural deductive logic is probably one of the hardest courses in the entire Faculty of Arts in terms of its learning curve. Its made easier by an incredibly helpful and caring professor, but be prepared for a workout, and if you start missing lectures and falling behind drop the course asap, you're f'ed
Brilliant. Best course I've taken at SFU!

Although his explanations can be arduous and his textbook needs to be 'dumbed down' some, he's still a very reasonable and fair man.  He really wants people to understand logic, and is willing to invest whatever time is necessary for that to happen.

Such a charm. Wonderous, witty and extremely elegant. His teaching style may be slighty ambiguous for some, but he is always willing to give you some of his time to help, no matter how time consuming the task may be.
He's hot but the worst teacher I've ever had.

Super nice guy.  The textbook is long and extraneous, but it's possible to weed out the important stuff from his powerpoints and from the sample exams.  Don't even look at the study guide, it was not tested.  Memorize the defs and metatheory.  Class was easy if you invest the time to do that.

Makes things uttlerly obscure, when they could be easy and fun.  Tries awfully hard to help students, but can't manage to explain anything clearly or concisely. I find this odd, considering the nature of the subject. Should spend less time helping students in off hours and more editing his text book

Ray is a very nice person who seems to care about his students. He is not, however, a particularly gifted teacher. Unless you're the sort of person who is used to thinking very mathematically, I would strongly advise against this course.

you MUST do the assignments (quite easy). right there you would get 50% of your grade alone. pass the exams and you'll get at least a b-. exams are little tricky tho. vey nice prof. an elegantly funny Brit. he really wants you to learn. best prof ever.
The exams are a little tricky but half of the grade comes from the assignments and pre-midterm which are very easy.
Easy, clear, and will give you postpone if you asked.  Exams are almost the copy of the sample he gives you. But the exam is mostly definitions.
super nice guy.. class would be difficult without his great help
Is helpful and fun. But his lectures soon become boring when you stare at his powerpoint slides day by day. Lecture attendance is dropping.
Amazing course. Although the material is extremely difficult, Dr Jennings makes it as clear as anyone can. He is very kind and patient.
Very animated and enthusiastic, and loves his field.
Very nice and willing to help!  Really wants his students to like logic!
